comments.body: Is the -resultobj required?
Yup, prefer to not touch those until we have decided what to do with them.
-resultobj again?
Yup, prefer to not touch those until we have decided what to do with them.
Random newline?
Nope, just a cleanup of trailing whitespaces. My editor makes them quite obvious, so I remove them.

I've never used this module before but after looking at the existing UI I'm quite confused. Honestly I think we should look into simplifying it a bit more. My thoughts are;

* `app_parameters` is designed to take in a dict/hashtable according to the docs and that seems wrong
* `app_parameters_free_form` is meant to be a string of parameters which is more what I expect but the name of the option isn't that great
* Ultimately a dict/hashtable is a poor way of defining some args considering the YAML syntax makes it hard to start keys with `-`

I'll leave it up to you whether you want to address this in this change or in a future PR but I think we should do is;

* deprecate the `app_parameters_free_form` option
* have `app_parameters` accept a string, list, or dict/hashtable but deprecate the dict/hashtable form as it is confusing
* potentially change `app_parameters` to be just `arguments` or `parameters` and have `app_parameters` as an alias for this

Let me know your thoughts, obviously you used or have a need for this module so would know more.

It's also exactly what I think, as I wrote in my previous comment in a summary form: 
> => I suggest removing app_parameters_free_form, have app_parameters accept both a simple string or a list, as it's done in other modules like win_package, and abandon the dict support (IMHO not really helpful).

However, for the renaming of `app_parameters`, I'm less convinced because this name match the internal name used by nssm, but this can be discussed later:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3837104/44775025-dd2bee80-ab74-11e8-8bbe-17b4314977c3.png)

The goal of this first PR remains to fix the current codebase in the simplest and fastest way so that it can be merged quickly and maybe backported.

I totally agree that this module would require a lot more changes, improvements, and features addition (including check mode support), but I prefer to address this in futures PRs to avoid mixing bug fixes, feature requests and breaking changes and delay this first PR ;)

Cool if the nssm refers to it as AppParameters then keeping the name sounds good, I wasn't aware of this. Perfectly fine for all this to be resolved in future PRs just wanted to bring out my concerns with the current UI.
As stated in https://github.com/jborean93, let's add an explicit check and error our if the value is a `Hashtable` and not a string. We should also deprecate this option and remove in 2.12.

Let's rename to `arguments` and have `app_parameters_free_form` as an alias for this. Up to you as to whether you want to add support for a list or arguments or not but my recommendation is to keep that for another PR.

I would avoid adding aliases for new module options. Try and stick with common option names like `chdir` or one that's resource specific. I would keep aliases for times where you need to make backwards compatible changes.

I wasn't sure which one to choose. `app_directory` is the most consistent in the resource context (same name of [the underlying nssm parameter](https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/ba8cb456d5050206d57db25803a987c5fe36e27c/lib/ansible/modules/windows/win_nssm.ps1#L386), and match with `app_parameters`), but other Ansible modules use `working_directory` (win_scheduled_task) or `chdir` (win_command, win_psexec, win_shell) for this usage. Maybe I would opt for one of the last two. Any preference?
This is a personal choice, but I try and make sure variables that contain module options match the option name itself. In this case I would set this variable to `$arguments`.

I generally agree, except that `$arguments` is quite a generic name and conflicts with other variables used in the rest of the code, so I kept the `app` prefix as for the other variables. Should I rename it anyway ?

Is there any differences between `nssm status <service>` vs `Get-Service -Name <service>`? In case it isn't, it would be better to use `Get-Service` as you won't have to scrape the stdout and you have enum like values to compare.

This should be roughly equivalent to `(Get-Service -Name <service>).Status` with some slight adaptations.
This is one perfect example among others in relation to my question about using basic Powershell commands over NSSM executable.
There is also all the code used to start/stop the service (`Invoke-NssmStart` / `Invoke-NssmStop` / `Start-NssmService` / `Stop-NssmService`), which may be replaced by simple Powershell commands. But this module is intended to use nssm, so I do'n't know if we should replace it when possible.
The Get-NssmServiceStatus cmdlet is now part of the deprecated code path and will be be removed in 2.12, so I think there is no more need to try to improve it.
It seems like a lot of these operations are stop then start. I'm wondering whether there's a way to continue a service for the scenarios where it is paused.

`win_service` handle that a lot better and use `Resume-Service`. This also joins the questions about NSSM vs Powershell and `win_nssm` vs `win_service`.
I'll almost tend to propose to copy/paste [the Set-ServiceState cmdlet](https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/ba8cb456d5050206d57db25803a987c5fe36e27c/lib/ansible/modules/windows/win_service.ps1#L303) from `win_service` to replace the start/stop stuff of this module...

This part of code is deprecated now. As decided in [a meeting](https://meetbot.fedoraproject.org/ansible-windows/2018-11-27/ansible_windows_working_group.2018-11-27-20.00.html), the service execution state can be controlled by the win_service module.

This is one of those cases where it is better to use WMI to manage the credentials. Using nssm means you are exposing the username/pass to anyone who is looking and are subject to escaping issues. The escaping issues are a slightly moot point because of `Argv-ToString` but still a factor to consider.

I totally agree that this parameter is not very well implemented. Here again, `win_service` [already handle service account a lot better](https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/ba8cb456d5050206d57db25803a987c5fe36e27c/lib/ansible/modules/windows/win_service.ps1#L173), with WMI. 

So either we copy/paste the code from `win_service` (or we create `Ansible.ModuleUtils.Service.ps1` to share the code), either we drop this parameter in favor of advising the user to use `win_service` directly.

Same thing for `description`, `display_name`, `start_mode`, and maybe `dependencies` parameters.
This parameter has been deprecated now.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +459,463 @@
            # Use custom compare callback to test only the username (and not the password)
            Update-NssmServiceParameter -parameter "ObjectName" -arguments @($fullUser, $password) -compare {param($actual,$expected) $actual[0] -eq $expected[0]} @common_params
        }
        $mappedMode = $start_modes_map.$startMode

comments.body: This is a good case of using https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/devel/lib/ansible/module_utils/powershell/Ansible.ModuleUtils.SID.psm1 to get a sid for comparison or just for converting to NTAccount to get the user's full account name.
This parameter has been deprecated now.
